Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Scientific Software Innovation Institute for Advanced Analysis of X-Ray and Neutron Scattering Data (SIXNS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
SUMMARY

The Office of Cyberinfrastructure, Division of Materials Research, and Chemistry Division contribute funds to this award.

This award supports a conceptualization effort to design a Sustainable Software Innovation Institute to elevate the level of scientific computing in X-ray and neutron scattering science. This conceptualization project will define the priorities of users and facilities to serve a significant fraction of the community of 14,000 annual users of X-ray and neutron scattering facilities in the U.S. The Institute aims to adapt modern methods of computational materials science to predict scattering from materials. It would incorporate these software tools into workflows for scattering scientists, giving them new pathways to scientific discovery.

Since 1980, the performance per dollar of computer hardware has increased by a factor of 100 every decade. Over the same time period, this million-fold improvement has been closely matched by the increased brilliance of X-ray sources, and in the past decade the performance of neutron sources has increased by a factor of ten. These improvements should be multiplied by comparable factors to account for improvements in software and methods of computational science, and for major improvements in optics and detectors for X-rays and neutrons. These enormous advances in computing and in scattering have occurred independently. Today there are exciting opportunities for combining them to do new science, and there is a growing body of work in computational scattering science that does so. Today this is only a small fraction of the work done by users of the synchrotron and neutron sources in the U.S., but it accounts for a disproportionately large fraction of high impact publications.

The conceptualization process will shape and assess envisioned activities of the Institute in the areas of workflow, uncertainty quantification, new avenues for discovery, and education.

An important activity of the Institute will involve developing new computational workflows that open channels for discovery in scattering science. This can be as direct as offering a common environment for comparing results from experiment to results from computational materials science. Computing also facilitates the combined analysis of information from different types of experiments, linked by an underlying model of the structure and dynamics of a material. Such a combined approach requires the assessment of uncertainties in the model using mathematical methods that are not yet standard practice in scattering science. This conceptualization project will develop a path to obtaining appropriate uncertainty analysis tools for a computationally enabled scattering science.

Workflows that include calculations of the structure and dynamics of materials can allow experimental results to be interpreted on a more fundamental level, letting scientists explore properties that are not measured directly by experiment opening new avenues to discovery.

This project supports aspects of the Materials Genome Initiative.

The Institute will bring materials simulation to train the next generation of scattering scientist. The Institute aims to broaden participation, particularly of women in computational science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a conceptualization phase award. Besides Brent Fultz at Caltech, the other lead scientists were John Rehr of Univ. Washington, Seattle, and Simon J.L. Billinge of Columbia University. Amber Boehnlein, now at Jefferson Lab, and Mark Stalzer, now at Caltech, were also part of the team at different times.

What we did was community organization of the scientific community and planning for a Sustainable Software Innovation Institute. The focus was on x-ray and neutron scattering, and how modern computing would allow scattering experiments to make more, and deeper scientific discoveries. The type of discoveries would be how atoms are arranged in materials, how they move, and how mechanical, chemical and electrical properties of materials originate from the behavior of atoms and electrons. Most of what we know about how atoms are arranged in materials has been learned by x-ray scattering experiments over the past century, and new discoveries are occurring rapidly as the experiments become more sophisticated. How atoms and electrons move when heated is also a topic of many scattering experiments with x-rays and neutrons. The attached figure of Moore's Law for computing has a superposition of x-ray brilliance. It shows that both computing and scattering are improving exponentially. To date, however, there has been little effort to connect these capabilities. SIXNS would do this by developing efficient computational workflows to connect materials theory to scattering experiments. Such an institute could have an enormous impact among many scientists, including the 14,000 annual users of x­ray and neutron scattering facilities in the U.S.

In the course of this conceptualization phase, we faced a growing realization of a synergy in using the same computational methods for calculating the Gibbs free energy of materials, G(T,P). The Gibbs free energy is important for all materials because it determines how a material is stable at a given temperature or pressure (for example, is it a solid or a liquid?). The common method for both scattering and thermodynamics could be "ab initio molecular dynamics" (AIMD), which amounts to making a movie with a detailed sequence of snapshots of atoms in a material as they vibrate. AIMD calculations of the free energy are possible today, but they require orders of magnitude more computing power than static simulations without temperature. Temperature is, of course, essential for understanding most useful properties of materials, and understanding the effects of temperature is a new opportunity for high-performance computing in materials science. It will serve well the needs of materials discovery within the Materials Genome Initiative.

To assess needs and build the case for a SIXNS Institute, three workshops were held to elicit community input. The first workshop at Caltech (Pasadena CA)  Jan. 31 ­ Feb. 2, 2013 focused on workflow strategies. The second workshop at Brookhaven National Laboratory (Upton, NY) on Aug 14­15, 2013, followed the theme of Advanced Analysis of X­ray and Neutron Scattering Data: Getting from data to science.  The third workshop held in January 17­18, 2014 at the University of Washington (Seattle, WA) focused on theoretical codes, analysis software, and software integration tools needed in a sustainable SIXNS Institute. Two Workshop Reports, largely written by the community of attendees, demonstrated the utility of SIXNS. They can be downloaded here

http://s2i2.caltech.edu/main/

http://www.feffproject.org/sixns­workshop­uw.html

As a result of these efforts, we drafted a plan for an S2I2 Institute to build a community of scientists who would calculate the Gibbs free energies of solids, and use the underlying AIMD calculations to obtain other important properties of materials.
